text:
Something I'm thinking about right now -- We want our blog to be primarily brand content that is insightful, valuable, and content that our current community is going to read and share _but_ I still need a place to publish content that is written primarily for search.

Increasingly, I think this content is too different to exist well together. Content that is optimized for the broad search goals of someone who has never heard from us before has a purpose, but it's never going to be content I want to put front-and-center. It's too general, and good search content often has a different tone and structure as well. It feels like it should be behind the scenes somewhere.

Does anyone have thoughts on this topic? Have you seen companies doing this well?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Two immediate thoughts: is there a "start here" or "beginners guide" section you could spin up?
and depending on how product-focused the SEO stuff is... you could put on the broader marketing site (rather than the blog)

Yeah that aligns with how I'm starting to think about this -- using guides or something like that for SEO content.

Intercom does an amazing job with branded content, but I know they do more search oriented content as well and I'm trying to suss out their strategy by looking at their site. It looks like their guides are gated (though not PDF downloads), which seems like it would hurt search, right?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
We publish a lot of both branded content and stuff that’s purely written for search. We’ve recently transitioned from a reverse-chronological feed of our articles to one where we can pin selected articles to /blog. We tend to use this for brand related content, which means our SEO content can sit in the background.

We also almost exclusively use email to promote our branded content. Since it’s not going after search traffic, it’s really one of the only ways we’re going to attract a ton of eyeballs to it.
ah! I like that. that definitely makes sense. Thanks for sharing!

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: The "front and center" remark you made reminds me of a misstep I make sometimes. The idea that our blog homepage is regularly visited by people to see what's next. Depends on the audience, but I suspect most people see indiv links come across their feeds or in inbox and rarely go to the page directly.

oh that's definitely true. I'm thinking a little more about the whole presentation of content on a website...whether that's links to core, evergreen content in the bottom nav or the vibe of your "resources" page.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Stephen King's On Writing is great! For copywriting, I always liked Hey Whipple Squeeze This <https://amzn.to/2lFvjVC>
For breaking down stories/novels, The Story Grid really analyzes the different types of genres & tropes <https://amzn.to/2netvDF>

This reminds me of Jimmy
Daly's post about publications vs a library. Most B2B content is a library, not a publication. I like the pinning of articles.

I also think Intercom had more of a brand strategy based on content rather than a search strategy with content. Hubspot, on the other hand, seemed to have a search first mentality. That's, of course, a simple breakdown.

We've been trying to manage this balance recently, too. One thing I would consider: "Search vs. Brand" content doesn't (or shouldn't) always mean "Beginner vs. Advanced."

Your brand can be your editorial standards, regardless of whether the topic is beginner, intermediate, or advanced.

I use the encyclopedia analogy: Every general encyclopedia has an article on Amelia Earhart. They have to. No one is breaking new ground. The content of those articles overlaps by probably 95%.

_But_ you may trust Britannica (clicking their result even when it's halfway down the SERP or starting your search on their homepage) to provide a well-written, trustworthy, up-to-date, and well-illustrated article about her (over, say, some poorly written, conspiracy-laden Wikipedia entry).

That's the real brand---not whether Britannica is or isn't covering basic or obscure topics but _the way_ that they cover them. If you can be consistent on that front, I think the question of whether beginner content is or isn't on brand fades a bit into the background.

100% agree that it's not beginner vs. advanced. I think of branded content as content with a strong point of view or opinion. That's not necessarily true for search content, maybe it should be, but I see a lot of companies who are very successful with search content that completely lacks a point of view.

And it is legitimately challenging to write highly optimized content for search with an interesting POV, the two goals feel different. But admittedly, I'm  coming from a much more editorial background so perhaps this is just a me problem :slightly_smiling_face:

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Definitely not a "you problem." Where I might disagree is that there even _is_ content without a point of view.

There are so many editorial choices that go into content (even search-focused content). The challenge, I guess, is that we're not very good at balancing search-engine and brand needs.

Last week, our team had a conversation about an opinionated piece on competitor analysis that we had 301'd to a search-focused piece on the same topic.

We incorporated the key opinions from the former into the search-focused piece, which, to me, was the ideal solution. But some people wanted to keep it as its own URL because it was "valuable."

If an idea is important enough to be central to our brand (and merit an editorial), we should find a way to incorporate that information into the core resource on the topic. That's how the maximum number of people get exposed to those ideas and how we differentiate our blog from others.

Here's a good example of search focused content without a POV: <https://blog.hubspot.com/service/customer-data-platform-guide>

It concludes with "Customer Data = Customer-Driven Marketing" which...ok...is something of an opinion, but you read this and know the author has very little personal interest or expertise in Customer Data Platforms.

So that's what I mean by search content that lacks a point of view. But often writing a well-optimized piece requires hitting certain points, and can be hard to do serve the needs of both brand and search.

It's great hearing that your team is struggling with how to do this as well :slightly_smiling_face: That does make me feel better. And in theory, it makes sense to combine both goals. In reality, I'm wondering if you can create a better reading experience by just intentionally serving those needs differently.

And I would love to see the example of the piece you wrote that incorporates opinion and search goals.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Totally get it. For a little while, we went down the path of trying to create separate "brand" vs. "search" content.

The thing that annoyed us was that everything turned into sort of "meh" content, which wasn't fun to create and generally a drag on the brand (while not _helping_ search in any way).

Ultimately, it seems like "search focused" is an excuse for not taking the time to gather and inject more opinions---to provide alternative perspectives that inevitably exist, even for introductory topics.

Those opinions are usually vital for understanding where a certain tactic or strategy does (or doesn't) fit into a broader marketing program.

For the example in question, we pulled quotes from a rant about why you shouldn't copy competitors and added it as an opening section to an otherwise boilerplate article on the topic: <https://conversionxl.com/blog/competitive-analysis/>

The above is far from a perfect example. It's a start. But the long-term goal is to do a much better at job integrating our perspective on competitive analysis (and everything else) into those comprehensive, relatively dry posts.

Yep. I hear what you're saying. Thank you for talking this through with me :slightly_smiling_face:  Really valuable to know that your team when down the path of separating the two goals and is now remerging them.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Alright, who's up for a content x SEO discussion?

Here's some open thoughts on content creation for the sake of ranking in search.

Modern SEO leans on a "central" page for a topic area, along with "supporting" pages. There are two well-known approaches for structuring content for a central page, and the query/intent + current SERP results can tell you a lot about which one is a better fit. I've been trying to work out a formula of when to use which format (and I'm still testing).

First, I see a lot of industry jargon thrown around in SEO and content: "content pillars" and "hub and spoke". To me, they're different formats. It's almost it's own rabbit hole to dive down, instead I'll see them as: Content pillars = long form pieces or 101 guides, and hub and spoke = table of content pieces.

Right now, I believe those ambiguous search terms like "applicant tracking" where the SERP is a mix of definitions, articles, product pages, and more, need the guide style pieces. Where as targeted searches like "how to start your own company", where the SERP turns up primarily articles or blog posts, could be used for ToC pieces.

Just an expansion upon this, and some analysis of content on the Shopify blog, we can see the use of both formats:

For guides, this blog `<https://www.shopify.com/blog/instagram-marketing>` ranks for a less specific but high traffic keyword "instagram marketing". When you dive into search insights and longer tail keywords on this topic, you can see that all folks are looking for is tips and strategies to use for their business—a thorough post or 101 guide (like we have provided) will do the trick to serve searchers what they're looking for. As we introduce other topics like hashtags, what to post on instagram etc. it allows us to link out to further articles that can target  other short tail keyword focused content in form of lengthy blogs or guides.

For ToC, this blog `<https://www.shopify.com/blog/ecommerce-business-blueprint>` ranks for a highly targeted, high volume term "how to start an ecommerce business". Why the ToC format works here is because actually answering that question would be so in depth that it would be next to impossible to include all that insight in one long form blog post. So, approaching answering this question would be best suited to writing this blog as if it were the contents page of book, i.e. understand the most vital areas surrounding the topic and send the reader on their way to the right "chapter" via an internal link to the content they seek.
Thanks for sharing this here Adam! Super informative lil' blurb.
To reiterate, this is a theory and not a fact. I'm more emphasizing, check what's on the SERP to guide you on what to create. I don't think it is as black and white as I've detailed here.

This "topic-agnostic" way to approach intent is probably useful for people with huge sites and tons of content.

One thing I might add: Since high-volume queries are less specific, they, by default, are made by people with varying intents. That, in turn, motivates Google to return several kinds of resources---indefinitely.

As a result, no matter which kind you create, there's greater risk as to whether it's the "right" kind, and you'll perpetually face higher competition: If an intent-ambiguous SERP includes three "comprehensive guides," that means you have only three spots for yours (compared to a SERP of nothing but comprehensive guides, in which you likely have more places to land).

I agree, the jargon around this stuff is confusing because there isn't really a single source of truth.

I've always taken hub and spoke to be a strategy where you target one overarching keyword (and its variations) on the main page (sometimes referred to as pillar content, though a pillar piece can stand on its own depending on the topic & competition), and then you break out subtopics (usually long tail keywords of target keyword) on separate pages. All subpages link back to main "hub" page.

For some of our clients in the legal industry we're moving to this spider-like content model to rank for their primary local keywords.

While we still employ a ToC on the hub page, we link out to separate pages as well to help strengthen the internal link profile of that page.
